verses.verse: ((1 He foretelleth them of false teachers,13 whose wicked sleights and destruction he declareth.12 He compareth them to bruit beasts,17 and to wells without water,20 because they seek to withdraw men from God to their old filthiness.) ) But (As in times past there were two kinds of Prophets, the one true, the other false, so Peter fortelleth them that there shall be some true and some false teachers in the Church, insomuch that Christ himself shall be denied by some, who notwithstanding shall call him redeemer.) there were false prophets also among the (Under the Law, while the state and policy of the Jews was yet standing.) people, even as there shall be false teachers among you: which privily shall bring in damnable heresies, even denying the Lord that hath bought them, and bring upon themselves swift damnation.
(There shall not only be heresies, but also many followers of them.) And many shall follow their destructions, by whom the way of truth shall be evil spoken of.

(Covetousness for the most part is a companion of heresy, and maketh merchandise even of souls.) And through covetousness shall they with feigned words make (They will abuse you, and sell you as they sell cattle in a Fair.) merchandise of you, (A comfort for the godly: God who cast the Angels that fell away from him headlong into the darkness of hell, at length to be judged, and who destroyed the old world with the flood, and preserved Noah the eight person, and who burned Sodom, and saved Lot, will deliver his elect from these errors, and will utterly destroy those unrighteous.) whose condemnation long since resteth not, and their destruction slumbereth not.

For if God spared not the (Cross references: : Job 4:18; Jude 6) Angels that had sinned, but cast them down into (So the Greeks called the deep dungeon under the earth, which should be appointed to torment the souls of the wicked in.) hell, and delivered them into (Bound them with darkness as it were with chains: and by darkness, he meaneth that most miserable state of life, that is full of horror.) chains of darkness, to be kept unto damnation:

Neither hath spared the (Which was before the Flood: not that God made a new world, but because the world seemed new.) old world, but saved (Gen. 7:1) Noah the eighth person a (For he ceased not for the space of an hundred and twenty years to warn the wicked both by word and deed, what wrath of God hanged over their heads.) preacher of righteousness, and brought in the Flood upon the world of the ungodly,
And (Gen. 19:1314) turned the cities of Sodom and Gomorrah into ashes, condemned them and overthrew them, and made them an ensample unto them that after should live ungodly,
And delivered just Lot vexed with the uncleanly conversation of the wicked:

(For he being righteous, and dwelling among them, in (Which way soever he looked and turned his ears.) seeing and hearing, (He had a troubled soul, and being vehemently grieved, lived a painful life.) vexed his righteous soul from day to day with their unlawful deeds.)
The Lord (Hath been long practiced in saving and delivering the righteous.) knoweth to deliver the godly out of tentation, and to reserve the unjust unto the day of judgment under punishment:

(He goeth to another sort of corrupt men, which notwithstanding are within the bosom of the Church, which are wickedly given, and do seditiously speak evil of the authority of Magistrates, (which the Angels themselves that minister before God, do not dispraise) A true and lively description of the Romish Clergy (as they call it.)) And chiefly them that walk after the flesh, in the lust of uncleanness, and despise government, which are bold, and stand in their own conceit, and fear not to speak evil of them that are in (Princes and great men, be they never so high in authority.) dignity.
Whereas the Angels which are greater both in power and might, give not railing judgment against them before the Lord.

(A lively painting out of the same persons, wherein they are compared to beasts, which are made to snare themselves to destruction, while they give themselves to fill their bellies: For there is no greater ignorance than is in these men, although they most impudently find fault with those things which they know not: and it shall come to pass that they shall destroy themselves as beasts, with those pleasures wherewith they are delighted, and dishonor and defile the company of the godly.) But these as natural brute beasts, led with sensuality and (Made to this end, to be a prey to others: so do these men willingly cast themselves into Satan’s snares.) made to be taken, and destroyed, speak evil of those things which they know not, and shall perish through their own (Their own wicked manners shall bring them to destruction.) corruption.

And shall receive the wages of unrighteousness, as they which count it pleasure daily to live deliciously. (Or, little rocks.) Spots they are and blots, delighting themselves in their deceivings, (When as by being amongst the Christians in the holy banquets which the Church keepeth, they would seem by that means to be true members of the Church, yet they are indeed but blots on the Church.) in feasting with you.

(He condemneth those men, as showing even in their behavior and countenance an inmeasurable lust, as making merchandise of the souls of light persons, as men exercised in all the crafts of covetousness, to be short, as men that sell themselves for money to curse the Sons of God after Balaam’s example, whom the dumb beast reproved.) Having eyes full of adultery, and that cannot cease to sin, beguiling unstable souls, they have hearts exercised with covetousness, they are the children of curse:
Which forsaking the right way, have gone astray following the way of (Num. 22:23) Balaam, the son of Beor, which loved the wages of unrighteousness.
But he was rebuked for his iniquity: for the dumb beast speaking with man’s voice forbade the foolishness of the Prophet.

(Jude 12) (Another note whereby they may be well known what manner of men they are, because they have inwardly nothing but either utterly vain or very hurtful, although they make a show of some great goodness: but they shall not escape unpunished for it, because under pretence of false liberty, they draw men into most miserable slavery of sin.) These are (Which boast of knowledge, and have nothing in them.) wells without water, and clouds carried about with a tempest, to whom the (Most gross darkness.) black darkness is reserved forever.

For in speaking (They deceive men with vain and swelling words.) swelling words of vanity, they (They take them as fishes are taken with the hook.) beguile with wantonness through the lusts of the flesh them that were (Unfeignedly and indeed clean departed from Idolatry.) clean escaped from them which are wrapped in error,
Promising unto them liberty, and are themselves the (John 8:34; Rom. 6:20) servants of corruption: for of whomsoever a man is overcome, even unto the same is he in bondage.

(Matt. 12:45; Heb. 6:4) (It were better never to have known the way of righteousness, than to turn back from it to the old filthiness: and men that do so are compared to dogs and swine.) For if they, after they have escaped from the filthiness of the world, through the acknowledging of the Lord, and of the Savior Jesus Christ, are yet tangled again therein, and overcome, the latter end is worse with them than the beginning.
For it had been better for them not to have acknowledged the way of righteousness, than after they have acknowledged it, to turn from the holy commandment given unto them.
But it is come unto them according to the true proverb, (Prov. 16:11) The dog is returned to his own vomit: and the sow that was washed, to the wallowing in the mire.
